speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Good afternoon.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Today the Federal Open Market Committee decided to raise the target range for the federal funds rate by ¼ percentage point, bringing it to 1¼ to 1½ percent.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Our decision reflects our assessment that a gradual removal of monetary policy accommodation will sustain a strong labor market while fostering a return of inflation to 2 percent, consistent with the maximum employment and price stability objectives assigned to us by law.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Before saying more about our decision, I’ll review recent economic developments and the outlook.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Following a slowdown in the first quarter, economic growth stepped up to a solid 3¼ percent pace in the second and third quarters of the year.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Household spending has been expanding at a moderate rate, business investment has picked up, and favorable economic conditions abroad have supported exports.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Overall, we continue to expect that the economy will expand at a moderate pace.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: While changes in tax policy will likely provide some lift to economic activity in coming years, the magnitude and timing of the macroeconomic effects of any tax package remain uncertain.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Smoothing through hurricane-related fluctuations, job gains averaged 170,000 per month over the three months ending in November, well above estimates of the pace necessary to absorb new entrants to the labor force.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: The unemployment rate has declined further in recent months and, at 4.1 percent in November, was modestly below the median of FOMC participants’ estimates of its longer-run normal level.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Broader measures of labor market utilization have also continued to strengthen.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Participation in the labor force has changed little, on net, over the past four years.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Given the underlying downward trend in participation stemming largely from the aging of the U.S. population, a relatively steady participation rate is a further sign of improved December 13, 2017 conditions in the labor market.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: We expect that the job market will remain strong in the years Chair Yellen’s Press Conference FINAL ahead.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: You may have noticed that we altered the statement language about the labor market outlook.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: This change highlights that the Committee expects the labor market to remain strong, with sustained job creation, ample opportunities for workers, and rising wages.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: We anticipate some further strengthening in labor market conditions in the months ahead; however, we expect the pace of job gains to moderate over time as we gradually reduce the degree of monetary policy accommodation.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Allowing the labor market to overheat would raise the risk that monetary policy would need to tighten abruptly at a later stage, jeopardizing the economic expansion.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Even with a firming of economic growth and a stronger labor market, inflation has continued to run below the FOMC’s 2 percent longer-run objective.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: The 12-month change in the price index for personal consumption expenditures was 1.6 percent in October, up a bit from the summer but still below rates seen earlier in the year.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Core inflation—which excludes the volatile food and energy categories—has followed a similar pattern and was 1.4 percent in October.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: We continue to believe that this year’s surprising softness in inflation primarily reflects transitory developments that are largely unrelated to broader economic conditions.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: As a result, we still expect inflation will move up and stabilize around 2 percent over the next couple of years.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Nonetheless, as I’ve noted previously, our understanding of the forces driving inflation is imperfect.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: As emphasized in our statement, we will carefully monitor actual and expected inflation developments relative to our symmetric inflation goal.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And, as I’ve noted before, we are prepared to adjust monetary policy as needed to achieve our inflation and employment objectives over the medium term.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Let me turn to the economic projections that Committee participants submitted for this meeting.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: As always, participants conditioned their projections on their own individual views of appropriate monetary policy, which, in turn, depend on each participant’s assessment of the many factors that shape the outlook.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: The median projection for growth of inflation-adjusted gross domestic product, or real GDP, is 2½ percent this year and next and moderates to 2 percent by 2020, a bit above its estimated longer-run rate.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: The median projection for the unemployment rate stands at 4.1 percent in the fourth quarter of this year and runs close to 4 percent over the next three years, modestly below the median estimate of its longer-run normal rate.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Finally, the median inflation projection is 1.7 percent this year, 1.9 percent next year, and 2 percent in 2019 and 2020.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Compared with the projections made in September, real GDP growth is a little stronger, the unemployment rate is a bit lower, and inflation is essentially unchanged.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Participants generally identified changes in tax policy as a factor supporting this modestly stronger outlook, although many noted that much uncertainty remains about the macroeconomic effects of the specific measures that ultimately may be implemented.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Returning to monetary policy, for the past two years the FOMC has been gradually increasing its target range for the federal funds rate as the economy has continued to make progress toward our goals of maximum employment and price stability.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Our decision today continues this process.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: We still expect that the ongoing strength of the economy will warrant gradual increases in the federal funds rate.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: That expectation is based on our view that this rate remains somewhat below its neutral level—that is, the level that is neither expansionary nor contractionary and keeps the economy operating on an even keel.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Because the neutral rate currently appears to be quite low by historical standards, the federal funds rate would not have to rise much further to December 13, 2017 get to a neutral policy stance.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: But because we also expect the neutral level of the federal funds Chair Yellen’s Press Conference FINAL rate to rise somewhat over time, additional gradual rate hikes are likely to be appropriate over the next few years to sustain a strong labor market and stabilize inflation around our 2 percent longer-run objective.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Even so, the Committee continues to anticipate that the longer-run neutral level of the federal funds rate is likely to remain below levels that prevailed in previous decades.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: This view is consistent with participants’ projections of appropriate monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: The median projection for the federal funds rate is 2.1 percent at the end of next year, 2.7 percent at the end of 2019, and 3.1 percent in 2020.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Compared with the projections made in September, the median path for the federal funds rate is unchanged through 2019 and a touch higher in 2020.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: I should note that the economic outlook is highly uncertain, and participants will adjust their assessments of the appropriate path for the federal funds rate as their economic outlooks and views of the risks to the outlook change.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Policy is not on a preset course.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Additionally, the Committee’s balance sheet normalization program, initiated in October, is proceeding.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: As we’ve noted previously, changing the target range for the federal funds rate is our primary means of adjusting the stance of monetary policy, and we do not foresee a need to alter our balance sheet normalization program.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Hence, our statement no longer mentions this program.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Of course, we would be prepared to resume reinvestments if a material deterioration in the economic outlook were to warrant a sizable reduction in the federal funds rate.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Finally, I’d like to note that, although I have one more FOMC meeting to attend in the New Year, this will be my last scheduled news conference.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Over the next month and a half, I will do my utmost to ensure a smooth transition to my designated successor, Jay Powell.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: I am confident that he is as deeply committed as I have been to the Federal Reserve’s vital public December 13, 2017 mission.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Thank you for being such an attentive audience these past four years.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And, as always, Chair Yellen’s Press Conference FINAL I’ll be happy to take your questions.

speaker: MARTIN CRUTSINGER
sentence: I’m Marty Crutsinger, Associated Press.

speaker: MARTIN CRUTSINGER
sentence: Madam Chair, could you give us any insight into the discussion and how it dealt with the major tax changes that Congress is considering now?

speaker: MARTIN CRUTSINGER
sentence: There have been thoughts that with these changes happening at a time when the economy is already—with unemployment so low—that the Fed may be forced to increase its pace on rate hikes.

speaker: MARTIN CRUTSINGER
sentence: Did any of that discussion come up in your meeting?

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So, yes, we did discuss tax policy, and let me say that most of my colleagues factored in the prospect of fiscal stimulus along the lines of what’s being contemplated by Congress into their projections.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Now, I should emphasize that some have been incorporating those expectations into their projections throughout the year, so changes to the projections that you see since September should not be viewed as an impact—an estimate of the impact of the tax package.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And, in particular, broader expectations of changes to fiscal policy have been reflected in financial market conditions, I think, over the past year.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: For example, we have seen a significant increase in the stock market, and at least some portion of that, I would judge, likely partly reflected expected tax changes, and that effect—along with other financial market effects, which affects, for example, projected consumer spending and would have affected wealth—that’s been part of participants’ forecasts now for some time.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: I think my colleagues and I are in line with the general expectation among most economists that the type of tax changes that are likely to be enacted would tend to provide some modest lift to GDP growth in the coming years, and you see that—in part, that’s one of the reasons, I think, for the uptick you see in estimated growth and decline in the unemployment rate.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: The views of participants, I believe, have been informed by a wide range of analysis, including that of the Joint Committee on Taxation and other outside evaluators, and my sense is that their estimates are essentially in the same ballpark, although they recognize, as I emphasized, that there is considerable uncertainty about the impacts, and that will have to be monitored over time.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: More specifically, they tend to see the package as boosting both consumer spending and capital spending, to some extent.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Now, to the extent that the changes do have positive impact on the growth of potential GDP and longer-run growth, let me just say that this is something that, should it occur, would be very welcome to participants, as long as it’s consistent with the attainment of our employment and inflation objectives.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: I guess I would also urge you to remember that when you look at the projections, that there are many factors that affect those projections, and changes in tax policy—that’s only one of a number of factors, including incoming data that has, to some extent, altered the outlook for growth and inflation.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: All of that factors into the projections you see.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: But I think, bottom line, when you look at assessments of the funds rate path, participants continue to see gradual increases in the target range for the federal funds rate as being appropriate to sustain a strong labor market and bring inflation back to 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And, look—importantly, there is a lot of uncertainty about what the likely effects will be, and my colleagues and I will be committed, as always, to evaluating incoming data and altering the outlook as appropriate.

speaker: HARRIET TORRY
sentence: Harriet Torry with Dow Jones Newswires.

speaker: HARRIET TORRY
sentence: You and others at the Fed have said that soft inflation should be transitory.

speaker: HARRIET TORRY
sentence: Are you confident that that will still be the case, particularly regarding wage gains?

speaker: HARRIET TORRY
sentence: They’ve been pretty moderate in recent months, yet the December 13, 2017 economy is growing and confidence is high.

speaker: HARRIET TORRY
sentence: Is there something going on in the economy that’s Chair Yellen’s Press Conference FINAL making it difficult for businesses to raise wages?

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So it is true that incoming wage data suggests only modest upward pressure on wages.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: That leaves me—that’s one factor, along with the fact that inflation remains low—with feeling that even though we have a 4.1 percent unemployment rate, that the labor market is not overheated at this point.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Remember, the modest pace of wage gains also probably reflects slow productivity growth.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: But when you ask me about the outlook for inflation, you know, I’ve talked in detail about this in the past and recognize that there is uncertainty about what’s holding inflation down.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: But my colleagues and I continue to believe that the factors that are responsible this year for holding inflation down are likely to prove transitory.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: That said, we all agree that our inflation objective is extremely important.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: We recognize that there’s been a prolonged shortfall.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: This is a symmetric 2 percent inflation objective, and we continue to indicate that we’ll be monitoring inflation developments closely.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And so this is on the horizon and recognized to be one of the risks facing policy.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Nick Timiraos, the Wall Street Journal.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Chair Yellen, I wanted to follow up on the question about tax changes.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: When you addressed it earlier today, and when you spoke to Congress last month, you often describe that you would welcome higher growth in the context of the employment and inflation mandate.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: And I guess I wonder how you judge the major provisions of the House and Senate tax plans: the corporate rate cut, immediate expensing of big-ticket purchases, new rates for pass-throughs, temporary rate cuts for individuals.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Do you see those, on balance, boosting the productive capacity of the U.S. economy as opposed to simply increasing aggregate demand?

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: And, related to that, how would you view December 13, 2017 the benefit of such tax changes now, when the economy is nearing full employment, versus at Chair Yellen’s Press Conference FINAL earlier periods when there was greater resource slack?

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So I think my colleagues and I mainly see the likely tax package as boosting aggregate demand, but also having some potential to boost aggregate supply.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So changes on the corporate tax side—the reduction in the corporate tax rate, expensing—will lower the cost of capital.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And while there are a range of estimates and uncertainty about how much stimulus that will provide to investment, in general I would see some stimulus to investment.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: In terms of aggregate supply effects, a stronger pace of investment could boost capital formation and thereby raise productivity growth and potential GDP or output to some extent.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Exactly how large those effects might be remain uncertain, but that is a channel.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And I suppose it’s also possible—I’m uncertain how significant this would be—that lower marginal effective tax rates for those groups that will see them could boost labor supply.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And, again, there are a range of estimates in the literatures.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: I indicated I think participants have reviewed a number of pieces of analysis, including the Joint Committee on Taxation estimates, and the many outside analysts who have weighed in on this and been influenced by that kind of analysis—but there is a good deal of uncertainty about what the impacts would be.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And, to the extent that there are larger impacts than those analyses assume on aggregate supply or potential GDP, in the context of an economy that has had disturbingly low productivity growth, that would be welcome and could support faster GDP growth, at least for some period, without—you know, without creating a need to tighten monetary policy to offset that.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So there are potentially both demand and supply effects here.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So, importantly, you really don’t, at the end of the day, see very much change in the federal funds rate path.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Participants do December 13, 2017 recognize that the unemployment rate is lower than their estimates of its long-run sustainable Chair Yellen’s Press Conference FINAL rate, so I think we are in the vicinity of full employment.

speaker: HEATHER LONG
sentence: Heather Long from the Washington Post.

speaker: HEATHER LONG
sentence: You have mentioned that the Committee thinks there will be wage increases next year.

speaker: HEATHER LONG
sentence: I’m wondering if you could clarify if that is coming in part or mostly from the changes to the tax plan.

speaker: HEATHER LONG
sentence: Is that what the expectation is, would drive the wage increases?

speaker: HEATHER LONG
sentence: And I was also wondering, I’ve heard from so many female economists in academia and at the Fed about what an inspiration you’ve been to them and how melancholy they will be to see you go.

speaker: HEATHER LONG
sentence: I was wondering if you just had any final words to young females and minorities who may be looking to enter economics or a banking profession and rise to your level.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: I’m sorry, remind me of the first part of your question.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: [Laughter] HEATHER LONG.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Wages.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Wages, yes.

speaker: HEATHER LONG
sentence: Is the tax policy driving wage increase expectations?

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Well, I think, generally, in a strong labor market where many firms are having difficulty finding qualified workers, we would expect, just through normal demand and supply channels, to see some upward pressure on wage growth over time.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And as the labor market is tightened, we’ve seen some very gradual drift upward in wage gains.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: They remain—it remains at a low level, but I would expect, in the context of an ongoing strong labor market, to see some upward pressure.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And I believe that’s the main thing that my colleagues are factoring in.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: On your question on advice to women and minorities, in the Federal Reserve, my colleagues and I are very focused on wanting to see and do what we can to foster greater December 13, 2017 participation of women and minorities in economics.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: We would love to, if we could, increase Chair Yellen’s Press Conference FINAL our hiring ourselves of women and minorities, and we see that both women and minorities are studying economics in disproportionately and disturbingly low numbers.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Although the women in STEM fields generally are about even with men—represent about 50 percent—in economics, women majors constitute something like 30 percent of undergraduate majors, and there is disproportionate low enrollment of minorities.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: I will just say, from my own experience, I think economics is a terrific field.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: I’ve thoroughly enjoyed my career in economics and think there are many different paths that people can follow that lead to satisfying careers, and that there are very interesting and important questions that economics addresses.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And it is a great field, and I would like to encourage greater involvement and think that people will find that satisfying.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And, just in terms of the kinds of research that’s done in the field, I think also a greater diversity, more women and minorities, may change the focus to some extent of the questions that people choose to look at and the analysis that they bring and a range of thinking that bears on research.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And all of that would be a healthy development.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Steve Liesman, CNBC.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Every day, it seems, we look at the stock market, it goes up triple digits in the Dow Jones.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: To what extent are there concerns at the Federal Reserve about current market valuations, and do they now or should they, do you think, if we keep going on this trajectory—should that animate monetary policy?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Finally, maybe as a sign of what’s been going on with valuations, this cryptocurrency called bitcoin keeps going up every day.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: What is the policy of the central bank of the United States of the introduction, use, and incredible rise in popularity of bitcoin?

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: Okay.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So let me start, Steve, with the stock market generally.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: I mean, of course the stock market has gone up a great deal this year, and we have in recent months characterized the general level of asset valuations as “elevated.” What that reflects is simply the assessment that, looking at price/earnings ratios and comparable metrics for other assets other than equities, we see ratios that are at the high end of historical ranges—and so that’s worth pointing out.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: But economists are not great at knowing what appropriate valuations are.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: We don’t have a terrific record, and the fact that those valuations are high doesn’t mean that they are necessarily overvalued.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: We are in a—I’ve mentioned this in my opening statement, and we’ve talked about this repeatedly—likely a low interest rate environment, lower than we’ve had in past decades.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And if that turns out to be the case, that’s a factor that supports higher valuations.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: We’re enjoying solid economic growth with low inflation, and the risks in the global economy look more balanced than they have in many years.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So I think what we need to and are trying to think through is, if there were an adjustment in asset valuations or the stock market, what impact would that have on the economy, and would it provoke financial stability concerns?

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And I think when we look at other indicators of financial stability risks, there’s nothing flashing red there or possibly even orange.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: We have a much more resilient, stronger banking system, and we’re not seeing some worrisome buildup in leverage or credit growth at successive levels.1 So, you know, this is something that the FOMC pays attention to, but if you ask me, is this a significant factor shaping monetary policy now, well, it’s on the list of risks, it’s not a major—it’s not a major factor.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And then you asked about bitcoin, and there I would simply say that bitcoin at this time plays a very small role in the payment system.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: It is not a stable source of—store of value, and it 1 Chair Yellen intended to say that credit growth is not at excessive levels.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: December 13, 2017 doesn’t constitute legal tender.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: It is a highly speculative asset, and the Fed doesn’t really play Chair Yellen’s Press Conference FINAL any role—any regulatory role with respect to bitcoin other than assuring that banking organizations that we do supervise are attentive, that they’re appropriately managing any interactions they have with participants in that market and appropriately monitoring anti-money-laundering Bank Secrecy Act, you know, responsibilities that they have.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Has there been a directive, or, more importantly, has there been a directive about bitcoin to the banks and their dealings with bitcoin from the Federal Reserve?

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: I don’t believe there’s been anything specific about that, just, generally, banks have Bank Secrecy Act anti-money-laundering responsibilities, and this applies to bitcoin as it does in every other realm.

speaker: DONNA BORAK
sentence: Hi, Chair Yellen, Donna Borak with CNN.

speaker: DONNA BORAK
sentence: To return back to the prospective tax bill questions, in your view at all, is the Republican tax bill an ill-timed fiscal stimulus, and are you concerned at all it will wind up squandering the tools both the Congress and the Fed have when it comes time to dealing with a recession?

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So, look, I will just say that it is up to the Administration and Congress to decide on appropriate fiscal policy, and our job is to maintain our focus on employment and inflation.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: We continue to think, as you can see from the projections, that a gradual path of rate increases remains appropriate even with almost all participants now factoring in their assessment of the impact of the tax—the tax policy.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: You know, it is projected that the tax cut package will lead to additions to the national debt and boost, by the end of the horizon, the debt-to-GDP ratio.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And I will say—and this is nothing new, this is something I’ve been saying for a long time—I am personally concerned about the U.S. debt situation.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: It’s not that the debt-to-GDP ratio at the moment is extraordinarily December 13, 2017 or worrisomely high, but it’s also not very low.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And it’s projected, as the population continues Chair Yellen’s Press Conference FINAL to age and the baby boomers retire, that that ratio will continue to rise in an unsustainable fashion.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So the addition to the debt, taking what is already a significant problem and making it worse, is—it is of concern to me, and I think it does suggest that in some future downturn, which, well, could occur just for whatever reason, the amount of fiscal space that would exist for fiscal policy to play an active role, it will be limited—may well be limited.

speaker: SAM FLEMING
sentence: Sam Fleming from the Financial Times.

speaker: SAM FLEMING
sentence: A couple of longer-term questions.

speaker: SAM FLEMING
sentence: First of all, midway through the year you talked about the issue of whether inflation targets might need to be raised.

speaker: SAM FLEMING
sentence: There’s obviously been a lot more debate in the Fed’s system since then about this.

speaker: SAM FLEMING
sentence: It may not be an imminent issue, but do you expect it to be something the Fed should be discussing over the coming years as some sort of change to the inflation target?

speaker: SAM FLEMING
sentence: Second of all, the amount of stimulus tools that the Fed may have at its disposal when the next downturn strikes are fairly limited.

speaker: SAM FLEMING
sentence: One of the incoming governors, Marvin Goodfriend, has talked about the merits of negative interest rates.

speaker: SAM FLEMING
sentence: I just wondered whether you see that as a potential—or at least in theory, for the Fed to consider should it run out of other options.

speaker: SAM FLEMING
sentence: Thanks.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So right now the FOMC is not discussing or considering its inflation target.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: We do see inflation as likely moving up to target over the next couple of years, and I would say—you said our stimulus tools are limited.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: I would want to emphasize that if there were a negative shock to the economy, we do have some scope to cut the fed funds rate, and there are other tools available, ones that we have used previously: forward guidance and asset purchases.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So I think we’re not—I wouldn’t say that we’re out of ammunition, but certainly it’s been recognized—and I’ve emphasized myself that, in the longer run, we may be—and we’ll have to December 13, 2017 see how this works out, but we may be in low interest rate environments where it could prove Chair Yellen’s Press Conference FINAL useful to have additional scope to conduct monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And, in that context, I think additional research—the academic economists and others are thinking hard about what more could be done, and I think these are matters that are certainly worthy of further study.

speaker: SAM FLEMING
sentence: So you do believe that negative interest rates, at least in theory, are possible in the U.S. at some point if it should be necessary—at least in theory.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: So, I mean, on that I would say we have—that’s not something that we have studied inside the Fed to any considerable extent and haven’t seriously thought about using ourselves during this last downturn and recovery.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: We have watched what’s happened in other countries.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: I think that’s worthwhile.

speaker: CHAIR YELLEN
sentence: And I would say it’s an area that academics may have interest in in the future and is worthy of some study, but it hasn’t been part of the Fed’s agenda.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: Hi, Chair Yellen.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: Victoria Guida with Politico.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: I just wanted to ask you quickly, on the regulatory side, in your testimony to Congress recently you spoke positively about the Senate bank regulatory reform bill, and I was wondering if there are—beyond that bill—if there are tweaks to Dodd-Frank that you think might still be beneficial.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: And then, somewhat related, Governor Powell recently said that there are currently no U.S. banks that are too big to fail.
